content.description: Another fun route with balancy moves.  Basically, this climb is the .10c's little brother.  Crux around the 2nd to 3rd bolt, where the holds get sparse.  Climbing eases up just as you get to the roof.  Nice fun moves to pull the roof.
content.location:
This climb is the right-most bolted route with a roof found about 35 ft. up.

The wall (east-facing) receives morning sun but is fully shaded by 1:15ish in the summer.  It can be located by turning right from the beginning of the main trail and cutting slightly uphill until reaching the base of the wall.  There is a very faint trail leading up but tread lightly, as the area is very duffy and fragile.  The main face is very light orange and looks like junky rock, but it's actually solid, for the most part.

content.description: Very fun route.  Using balance and small holds keeps you on your toes until just after the 4th bolt, where the climb eases up a bit.  Somewhat technical, with the crux located between the 2nd and 4th bolts.
content.protection: 7 bolts, chains (shared with 5.9 to the right)
content.location:
This climb is tucked in between the other only two routes at this wall.

The wall (east-facing) receives full morning sun but is fully shaded by 1:15ish in the summer.  It can be located by turning right from the beginning of the main trail and cutting slightly uphill until reaching the base of the wall.  There is a very faint trail leading up but tread lightly, as the area is very duffy and fragile.  The main face is very light orange and looks like junky rock, but it's actually solid, for the most part.

content.description: All around pretty fun with holds that aren't as good as they look from the ground. A bit harder of a finish involves going straight up the face, but the corner can be used to make it easy. Good for the beginning climber/leader.
content.location:
This climb is the left-most bolted route on bulbous well-featured grey rock, just left of the crack.

The wall (east-facing) receives morning sun but is fully shaded by 1:15ish in the summer.  It can be located by turning right from the beginning of the main trail and cutting slightly uphill until reaching the base of the wall.  There is a very faint trail leading up but tread lightly, as the area is very duffy and fragile.  The main face is very light orange and looks like junky rock, but it's actually solid, for the most part.

content.description: Crux is the headwall at pins. Gear may need to be upgraded. Scary route.
content.location: Approach from south via a 4th class ramp. to a bolted belay. can be supplemented using large cams. Climb steep knobby face past baby angles in drilled holes, to a rounded ledge. Bring mid sized gear for final groove. Summit anchors were placed during the first ascent, can also use cordelettes on natural features. Can be top-roped.

content.description: Climbs the most prominent arete overhanging the road. Starts off the same 4th class ramp as The Raven.
content.location: Approach from the south on fourth class ramp that leads to the bottom of the main skyline arete. Same start as for the Raven. Climb up and right to the arete, follow the arete past a number of 3/8" bolts to the anchors. Amazing exposure and location!

content.description: A small little pillar at Eagle Rock. Pete and I climbed this a few years ago. I tried to put a bolt in on lead, but the rock is really weak. I was able to use a few cams and sling some stuff. I can’t remember what we did at the summit, but I think I just slung some big knobs or threaded something or maybe there’s a bolt up there. If you climb it bring some bail webbing to clean it up, but it’s easy to get off we didn’t do any crazy simul raps or anything sketchy.
content.protection: A few cams, definitely a yellow #2 and some others and some slings to tie off knobs and thread tunnels. There’s no runouts but gear is somewhat questionable due to bad rock quality.
content.location:
This is to climbers left of most of the other climbing routes. I think the easiest way is to walk up to the top of Eagle Rock, look down at the pillar, and then scramble down a gully to it.

Start in the notch and work your way up to the top.
